content:
I can't find out where TB gets the information telling it where the main mail store is.

At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡ > Account Settings > Server Settings > Message Storage The 'Local Directory' setting has the full path to your storage location.

When the storage location is outside the regular Thunderbird profile, someone (you?) did do this deliberately. Why did you do this in the first place?
creator: christ1

content:
I can't find out where TB gets the information telling it where the main mail store is.

At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡ > Account Settings > Server Settings > Message Storage The 'Local Directory' setting has the full path to your storage location. This is on a per account basis.

When the storage location is outside the regular Thunderbird profile, someone (you?) did do this deliberately. Why did you do this in the first place?
creator: christ1

content:
Yes, thank you, that's a work-around that I'm using. However, I was looking for the ability to "Add to Dictionary" when I *right-click* on a word with a wavy red line under it.

I've solved the problem. Under Tools > Settings > Composition > HTML Style, selecting the first option of "Variable Width" with size "Medium" causes the problem. I've tested dozens of other HTML Style settings and so far this is the only combination that causes the problem - any other Font is OK, and any other Variable Width size is OK. Surely this is a bug?

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)

Oltre a questo:

  • Quanto spazio libero hai sul disco?
  • A quando risale il backup più recente di cui disponi?

content:
Is it an issue with Thunderbird or should I take this up with my server provider.

Neither. What is your anti-virus software?

Click the 'Get Certificate' button at the exception pop-up, then the 'View' button.

Post a screenshot of the Certificate Viewer window with the issuer information visible.
creator: christ1

content:
Thanks for the reply.

I am using Norton 360 for antivirus.

Attached is the view of the certificate.
creator: pete102

content:
Thanks. As you can see in the screenshot, the Issuer of the cert Thunderbird is complaining about is Norton Antivirus. What is does is intercepting the secure TLS connection of Thunderbird to your email provider's server, in other words, a man in the middle attack. Norton is then generating a cert on the fly to terminate the TSL connection, and connecting to your email provider's server on your behalf. That also means Norton is able to spy all your seemingly TLS connected traffic, including your account passwords. So you do have two options.

  1. Install the root cert from Norton, so that Thunderbird will stop complaining about the Norton cert.
  2. Disable SSL/TLS scanning in Norton Antivirus, so that Norton won't be able to spy on you anymore. Better yet, get rid of Norton altogether, and stick with Microsoft Defender.

More information in this Firefox support article, it applies to Thunderbird as well. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/error-codes-secure-websites
creator: christ1

content:
Hi, I suggest you to create an inactive pop3 account so you can replace your msf file (I don't deal with sbd, so I don't know).

I use a Mac but it should be the same on Windows: Create a new mail account that does not exist, or maybe one that you only read online (I tried with vivaldi.net). As you type your e-mail, you may see a clickable label "configure manually" appear. Click on it so you can force "POP3" instead of IMAP. Thunderbird allows the creation of an account even if the datas are not valid. So do not type all the credential and keep the account even if it is not valid - all you need is that the folder structure is created. Then you have a final screen, the server settings, with the path to the storage folder. Head to it and quit Thunderbird. In the folder, paste a copy of your SBD files with their index (keep the originals safe!). Maybe you should rename them as the default files created to lure Thunderbird. Then restart Thunderbird and see if the fake account lists your e-mails.

For long term storage, I would advise to use the archive function on them in a local folder which IMO is the best storage for old e-mails. And get rid of the fake account.
creator: frederic12

content: Thanks frederic. I was thinking something like that might be the answer but it seemed pretty technical to attempt so was waiting for a reply here. What I've found that seems to be working is to copy over the pop .msf files and contents of the pop .sbd folders to new .sbd folders that I create under "Local folders" which are just that - local. It's a little tricky but is mostly working. I do the copying in the C:/User directories and then close and open Thunderbird to see what sticks. So far it's working pretty good.
